【薛收这里所问关乎"天人”。他问王通仲长子光是什么样的人。王通说:一位“天人”。仲长子光是一位和王通家熟识的人，王通的弟弟王绩与他志气相投。《新唐书》王绩的传里，提到过他："仲长子光者，亦隐者也,无妻子，结庐北渚，凡三十年,非其力不食”（《新唐书》列传121）。从中可知，这位子光先生是一位隐士，没有家庭，自食其力。王通对隐者都很客气。他把仲长子光称为"天人”。薛收于是想让老师解释"天人”的含义。王通答道：形体是渺小的，从这点看，仲长子光是一个人;然而思想是博大深远的，所以他成就了自己的天性。这样的人，就是"天人"---------个有天性的个体。薛收问："圣人与天地如何？"子曰："天生之，地长之，圣人成之。故天地立而《易》行乎其中矣。"（《魏相篇》）薛收问到了“圣人。” At that time, Elder Subhūti said to Deva Lord Śakra, “Kauśika, do you see any dharma that should be protected?” Deva Lord Śakra replied, “No, Most Virtuous One, I do not see any dharma that should be protected.” Subhūti said, Kauśika, if good men and good women speak like this, the most profound prajñā- pāramitā will itself be their protection. This you should know: whatever humans or non-humans might look for the chance to harm it, in the end they will be unable to do so. Kauśika, if you wish to protect it, you should do so in accordance with what has been said: for the bodhisattvas, [wishing to protect] the most profound prajñā-pāramitā is no different from wishing to protect empty space. The buddhas and ancestors of the ten directions [03:3] What is the essential point of the World-Honored One’s saying, “All living beings in their entirety have buddha nature”? It is turning the dharma wheel of the saying, “What thing is it that comes like this?”@1-38-5 One speaks of “living beings,” or “sentient beings,” or “the multitude of beings,” or “the multitude of types.”@1-38-6 The words “in their entirety have” refer to living beings, the multitude of beings.@1-38-7 That is, the “entirety of beings” is buddha nature; one entirety of the “entirety of beings” is called “living beings.”@1-39-8 At this very moment, the interior and exterior of living beings is the “entirety of beings” of buddha nature. This is not only the skin, flesh, bones, and marrow uniquely transmitted; for you’ve gotten my skin, flesh, bones, and marrow.@1-39-9 We should realize that the being that is here made the “entirety of beings” by buddha nature is not the being of being and non-being.@1-39-10 The “entirety of beings” is the word of the buddha, the tongue of the buddha, the eyes of the buddhas and ancestors, the nose of the patch-robed monk. Furthermore, the term “entirety of beings” is not initial being, not original being, not wondrous being, and the like; how much less is it conditioned being or deluded being.@1-39-11 It has nothing to do with the likes of mind and object, nature and mark.@1-39-12 Therefore, the secondary and primary recompense of the “entirety of beings” of living beings is not by any means the generative power of karma, not deluded conditioned arising, not of its own accord, not the practice and verification of spiritual powers.@1-39-13 Were the “entirety of beings” of living beings generated by karma, or conditioned arising, or of its own accord, the verification of the way of the sages as well as the bodhi of the buddhas and the eyes of the buddhas and ancestors would also be the generative power of karma, conditioned arising, and of its own accord. And this is not the case. In all the worlds, there is no adventitious dust at all; right here, there is no second person beyond this.@1-40-14 For “the root source is directly cut, but people have not noticed; the busy, busy karmic consciousness, when will it rest?”@1-40-15 It is not the being of deluded conditioned arising; for “in the realms everywhere, it has never been hidden.”@1-40-16 To say that “in the realms everywhere, it has never been hidden” is not necessarily to say that what fills the realms is being: [the notion] that the realms everywhere are my being is a false view of other paths.@1-40-17 It is not the being of original being; for it is throughout the past and throughout the present.@1-41-18 It is not the being of initial arising; for it does not admit a single dust mote.@1-41-19 It is not the being of individual instances; for it combines them. It is not the being of beginningless being; for “What thing is it that comes like this?”@1-41-20 It is not the being of initially arising being; for “my usual mind is the way.”@1-41-21 We should realize that, within the “entirety of beings,” living beings cannot readily be met.@1-41-22 When the understanding of the “entirety of beings” is like this, the “entirety of beings” is passing through the body and sloughing it off.@1-41-23

When the understanding of the “entirety of beings” is like this, [03:4] Many students, hearing the term “buddha nature,” have falsely reckoned that it is like the “I” in the other path of Śreṇika.@1-42-24 This is because they have not met a person, they have not met themselves, they have not seen a teacher.@1-42-25 They have foolishly thought that the mind, mentation, and consciousness moved by wind and fire are the perception and comprehension of buddha nature.@1-42-26 Who said that buddha nature has perception and comprehension?@1-42-27 While those who perceive and those who know may be buddhas, buddha nature is not perception and comprehension.@1-42-28 Much less does the perception with which one refers to the buddhas as perceivers and knowers represent the perception in the misunderstandings you talk on about, the perception of the motion and rest of wind and fire.@1-42-29 Just one or two faces of the buddhas and faces of the ancestors — this is perception.@1-42-30

[03:5] There have frequently been ancient elders and prior worthies who have gone to Sindh in the West and back or have guided humans and devas; from the Han and Tang through the court of the Song, they are like “rice, hemp, bamboo, and reeds.”@1-43-31 It is pitiful that many of them have thought that the movements of wind and fire are the perception of buddha nature. It is because they are estranged from the study of the way that they make this mistake.@1-43-32 Late students and beginners in the way of the buddhas today should not be like this. [03:10] A bunch in the past and present have frequently thought the words “if the time arrives” mean that one awaits a time later when buddha nature might appear. “Continuing to practice in this way,” they say, “one encounters the time when buddha nature appears naturally; if the time does not arrive, even though one studies with a teacher and asks about the dharma, even though one makes concentrated effort in pursuit of the way, it will not appear.”@1-46-50 Taking such a view, they return in vain to the red dust, they stare vacantly at the Milky Way.@1-47-51 Types like this are doubtless followers of an other path of natural occurrence.@1-47-52To say, “if you wish to know the meaning of buddha nature” is saying, for example, “you should know the meaning of buddha nature.”@1-47-53 To say “you should observe the conditions of the time” is to say, “you should know the conditions of the time.” If you wish to know what is called “buddha nature,” you should know that it is precisely “the conditions of the time.”@1-47-54 To say, “if the time arrives,” means “the time has already arrived; what is there to doubt?”@1-47-55 Let doubting the time be as it may, return buddha nature to me.@1-47-56 We should realize that “if the time arrives” is “not passing the twelve times in vain.”@1-47-57 “If it arrives” is like saying, “it has arrived.” If it were “if the time arrives,” buddha nature would not arrive; therefore, since the time has already arrived, this is the appearance of buddha nature.@1-48-58 Or “its principle will appear of itself.”@1-48-59 In sum, there has never been a time when the time does not arrive, nor a buddha nature that does not appear.@1-48-60* * * * * [03:10] A bunch in the past and present have frequently thought the words “if the time arrives” mean that one awaits a time later when buddha nature might appear. “Continuing to practice in this way,” they say, “one encounters the time when buddha nature appears naturally; Samādhi and the six powers [03:12] Thus, these “mountains, rivers, and the whole earth” are all the ocean of buddha nature. To say that they “are all constructed dependent upon it” means that the very time they are constructed is the “mountains, rivers, and the whole earth.” Since it is said that they “are all constructed dependent upon it,” we should realize that such is the shape of the ocean of buddha nature; it has nothing beyond this to do with inside, outside, or in between.@1-49-63 If such is the case, to see the mountains and rivers is to see buddha nature; to see buddha nature is to see an ass’s jaw and a horse’s muzzle.@1-49-64 “All . . . dependent,” we understand — and we do not understand — as “wholly dependent,” as “dependent on the whole.”@1-49-65 “Samādhi and the six powers appear from here”: we should realize that the “appearance” and the non-appearance of the samādhis are equally “all dependent” on buddha nature; the “from here” — and the not “from here” — of the whole of the six powers are both “all dependent” on buddha nature.@1-49-66 The six spiritual powers are not just the six spiritual powers spoken of in the teachings of the āgamas: “six” means that “three three in front, three three in back” are the pāramitāof the six spiritual powers.@1-49-67Therefore, do not investigate the six spiritual powers as being “perfectly clear, the tips of the hundred grasses; perfectly clear, the intention of the buddhas and ancestors.”@1-50-68 Although they may be constricted by the six spiritual powers, they are obstructions in the flow to the source in the ocean of buddha nature.@1-50-69 * * * * *

Although they may be constricted by the six spiritual powers, [03:13] The Fifth Ancestor, Chan Master Daman, was from Huangmei in Qizhou.@1-50-70 He was born without a father and gained the way as a child; he was actually the Pine-Planting Practitioner.@1-51-71 First, when he was residing on Mount Xi in Qizhou planting pines, he encountered the Fourth Ancestor on an outing there.@1-51-72[The Fourth Ancestor] addressed the Practitioner, “I want to transmit the dharma to you, but your years are already full. If you wait till you come again, I’ll wait for you.”@1-51-73The Master agreed.Thereafter, he went to a woman of the Zhou Clan for rebirth. Upon being thrown into a dirty waterway, he was protected by spiritual forces and was unharmed for seven days. And so, [his mother] took him up and raised him. As a boy of seven, he met the Fourth Ancestor, Chan Master Dayi, on the road in Huangmei. The Ancestor saw that, although a child, the Master’s physiognomy was remarkably fine, different from that of an ordinary child.Seeing this, the Ancestor asked, “What’s your surname?” The Master answered, “I have a surname, but it’s not an ordinary surname.” The Ancestor said, “What is this surname?” The Master answered, “It’s Buddha Nature.”@1-51-74The Ancestor said, “You have no buddha nature.”@1-51-75The Master replied, “It’s because buddha nature is empty that you say I have none.” The Ancestor, recognizing that he was a vessel of the dharma, had his acolyte go to his house and beg his parents to permit him to leave home.@1-51-76 Because of the karma of his previous life, his parents had no objection whatsoever and relinquished him to become a disciple. Later, he transmitted the treasury of the true dharma eye. [The Master] resided on Mount Dong in Huangmei, where he greatly wielded the dark style.@1-52-77

[03:23] Generally speaking, there are few predecessors who have clarified the principle of buddha nature. The masters of the teachings of the āgamas and the sūtras and treatises could not be expected to know it; only descendants of the buddhas and ancestors uniquely transmit it. The principle of buddha nature is that one is not endowed with buddha nature before attaining buddhahood: one is endowed with it after attaining buddhahood. It is buddha nature always studies together with attaining buddhahood.@1-58-113 This principle, we should fully investigate and make concentrated effort on; we should make concentrated effort on and investigate it for twenty or thirty years. It is not something clarified by the ten sages and three worthies.@1-59-114 To say, “living beings have buddha nature,” “living beings have no buddha nature,” is this principle. To study this as the dharma that one is endowed [with buddha nature] after attaining buddhahood is right on the mark. If it is not studied in this way, it would not be the buddha dharma; if it had not been studied in this way, the buddha dharma would not have reached us today. Those who have not clarified this principle have not clarified, have not seen or heard of, attaining buddhahood. have not seen or heard of, [03:24] Therefore, the Fifth Ancestor said to him, “A person of Lingnan has no buddha nature.” When one first sees the buddha and hears the dharma, what is difficult to acquire, difficult to hear, is that “living beings have no buddha nature”; whether from a wise friend, whether from a sūtra scroll, what is a joy to hear is that “living beings have no buddha nature.”@1-59-115 Those who have not studied their fill of seeing, hearing, perceiving, and knowing that “all living beings have no buddha nature” have not yet seen, heard, perceived, or known buddha nature.@1-59-116 When the Sixth Ancestor sought solely to “become a buddha,” the Fifth Ancestor, in order to make a buddha of the Sixth Ancestor, had no other words, no other ingenious device: he just said, “A person of Lingnan has no buddha nature.” We should recognize the fact that speaking and hearing of “no buddha nature” — this is the direct path to “becoming a buddha.” Therefore, the very time of “no buddha nature” is just then “becoming a buddha.” Those who have not yet seen or heard, who have not yet spoken of, “no buddha nature” have not yet “become a buddha.”

The meaning of buddha nature [03:39] Among the prior and later skin bags who have seen and heard the buddha dharma that has now spread among devas and humans and throughout the dharma realms of the great chiliocosm, who else has said that the form of the body manifesting is buddha nature?@1-73-179 In the great chiliocosm, only Venerable Kāṇadeva has said it. The others say only that buddha nature is not something the eye sees or the ear hears or the mind knows; they have not said it because they do not know that the body manifesting is buddha nature. It is not that the Ancestral Master begrudged [teaching them], but they close their eyes and ears and cannot see or hear him. [03:41] Neverthess, following the master and disciple Nāgārjuna and Kāṇadeva, in prior and later generations throughout all quarters in the three countries, people who have occasionally studied Buddhism, have never said anything like Nāgārjuna and Kāṇadeva.@1-75-187 How many sūtra masters and treatise masters have missed the words of the buddhas and ancestors?@1-75-188 In the Land of the Great Song, from long ago, in trying to paint this episode, being unable to paint it on their bodies, paint it on their minds, paint it on the sky, paint it on a wall, they have pointlessly painted it with a brush, depicting on a dharma seat the form of a disk that is like a mirror and taking it as this [scene of] Nāgārjuna’s body manifesting a round moon form.@1-75-189 Already for hundreds of years of frost and flowers blossoming and falling, although they would have formed gold dust in people’s eyes, no one has said they are wrong.@1-75-190 What a pity that everything has gone amiss like this.@1-75-191If we understand the body manifesting a round moon form to be the form of a disk, it is a real painted cake.@1-76-192 To play around with that — what a laugh!@1-76-193 How sad that not a single one among the householders and renunciants in the entire Land of the Great Song has heard or known Nāgārjuna’s words, has penetrated or seen Kāṇadeva’s saying — much less has been intimate with the body manifesting. They are in the dark about the round moon; they have made the full moon wane.@1-76-194 This is neglect of investigating the ancient; it is lack of admiration for the ancients.@1-76-195 Old buddhas and new buddhas, going on to meet the real body manifesting, do not enjoy the painted cake!@1-76-196

In the autumn of the junior water year of the sheep, the sixteenth year of Jiading, I went to the Guangli Chan Monastery on Mount Ayuwang.@1-79-208 On the wall of the west corridor, I saw painted illustrations of the thirty-three ancestors of Sindh in the West and the Land of the East.@1-79-209 At the time, I had no grasp of them. Nevertheless, that the body manifesting is the round moon form [03:44] In sum, because they have not awakened from the view that buddha nature is our present thinking and perceiving, they seem to have lost the point from which to penetrate either the words “have buddha nature” or the words “have no buddha nature,” and even those who study that we should speak of them are rare.@1-80-217 We should realize that this neglect is due to a decline. Among the heads of meals in all quarters, there are even those who have spent their entire lives without ever speaking of buddha nature.@1-80-218 Or they say, “those who listen to the teachings talk of buddha nature; those robed in clouds who study Zen shouldn’t speak of it.”@1-81-219 The lot like this are really beasts.@1-81-220 What minions of Māra are these that have infiltrated our way of the buddhas, the tathāgatas, and seek to defile it? Is there something called “listening to the teachings” in the way of the buddhas? Is there something called “studying Zen” in the way of the buddhas? We should realize that there has never been anything called “listening to the teachings” or “studying Zen” in the way of the buddhas. * * * * *

[03:46] We should quickly investigate the words “all living beings.” The deeds and paths, secondary and primary recompense, of “all living beings” are not the same, and their views are various.@1-82-222 They will variously be a common person, a follower of an other path, or on the three vehicles or five vehicles, and so on.@1-82-223 In “all living beings” spoken of here on the way of the buddhas, those with mind are all living beings; for mind is living beings.@1-82-224 Those without mind are similarly living beings; for living beings are mind.@1-82-225 Therefore, all minds are living beings, and living beings all “have buddha nature.” The grasses, trees, and lands are mind; because they are mind, they are living beings; because they are living beings, they “have buddha nature.” The sun, moon, and stars are mind; because they are mind, they are living beings; because they are living beings, they “have buddha nature.”@1-82-226[The words] “have buddha nature” said by the National Teacher are like this. If they were not like this, they would not be the “having buddha nature” said on the way of the buddhas.@1-82-227 The essential point of what the National Teacher says here is only that “all living beings have buddha nature”; to take this further, those who are not living beings would not “have buddha nature.”@1-82-228Let us for the moment ask the National Teacher, “Do all buddhas have buddha nature?” We should ask him and test him like this. once addressed the assembly, saying, [03:48] Among the humans and devas hearing this, there are those of great capacities who rejoice and no lack of those who are alarmed and dubious. What Śākya, the Honored One, says is “all living beings in their entirety have buddha nature”; what Dawei says is “all livings beings have no buddha nature.” There is a big difference between the meanings of “have” and “have no,” and which saying is correct must have been doubted. [03:50] Hence, Baizhang said, “To talk of living beings having buddha nature is to denigrate the buddha, dharma, and saṃgha; to talk of living beings having no buddha nature is to denigrate the buddha, dharma, and saṃgha.”@1-86-247Thus, both saying “have buddha nature” and saying “have no buddha nature” become denigration. Though we say they become denigration, this does not mean one should not say them. Now, let us ask you, Dawei and Baizhang: we should ask a bit, it is not that there is no denigration, but have you talked of buddha nature or not? [03:51] * * * * * Chan Master Dazhi of Mount Baizhang addressed the assembly saying,@1-87-250Buddha is the supreme vehicle, is the highest wisdom, is this person established by the way of the buddhas, is a buddha having buddha nature.@1-87-251 [One such as this] is a guiding teacher, is making use of an unobstructed style, is unobstructed wisdom. Henceforth, one can make use of cause and effect, and is free in merit and wisdom; one becomes the cart that carries cause and effect@1-87- 252 In life, one is unarrested by life; in death, one is unobstructed by death. In the five aggregates, like a gate opening, one is unobstructed by the five aggregates: one goes and stays freely, leaves and enters without difficulty. If one can be like this, there is no issue of rank or stage, superiority or inferiority, even down to the body of an ant; if one is simply like this, everything is the pure and wondrous land, inconceivable.{1:36} [03:52] This is Baizhang’s statement. The “five aggregates” are the present body that “won’t be destroyed”; the present hasty act is “a gate opening,” is “unobstructed by the five aggregates.”@1-88-253 In making use of life, one is not arrested by life; in making use of death, one is not obstructed by death. Do not futilely love life; do not irrationally fear death. Since they are the locus of buddha nature, to be moved by them or to reject them is an other path. To recognize the conditions right before one is “making use of the unobstructed style.” This is “this buddha” that is “the supreme vehicle.”@1-88-254 The location of “this buddha” is “the pure and wondrous land.” * * * * *

[03:76] Thus, although the days and months are long during which we have been mistaken in our half a “study of the marginal matters of the buddha dharma,” this is the dog forcing entry into this bag of skin. While it is “knowingly committing an intentional crime,” it is “having buddha nature.” [03:76] Thus, although the days and months are long during which we have been mistaken in our half a “study of the marginal matters of the buddha dharma,” this is the dog forcing entry into this bag of skin. While it is “knowingly committing an intentional crime,” it is “having buddha nature.” 文中子答道： "从前圣贤的君主执掌政权，怎么会赏罚不明呢?《元经》对晋惠帝以后的君王进行褒贬，以此取代赏罚，就是因为此后天下没有明君，赏罚不公，所以才从晋惠帝开始啊!"薛收又问："那么，《春秋》记事始于周平王、鲁隐公，也是出于同样的考虑吗？"文中子答道："是啊，只是没有人明白这些道理。"薛收说:"我现在才知道天下大治，是因为有圣贤之人执政；而天下大乱，是因为没有圣贤之人执政。圣人得以执政，那么赏罚分明的制度才得以推行；圣人若无缘于朝政，他们则会编写褒贬议论朝政的著作，以促使国家统治的准则制度得以重建，同时道德文明不至于败坏。这难道不是深奥的治国之道吗？"薛收向老师叩谢退出，把与老师的对话内容告诉了董常。董常感叹："孔子虽然辞世了，但其思想对现在还有深远影响啊!"文中子说："太高超了！周公和孔子的思想，简直像神灵创造的一样。遵循他们的思想则吉利，违背他们的思想则遭殃。" although the days and months are long during which we have been mistaken in our half a “study of the marginal matters of the buddha dharma,” this is the dog forcing entry into this bag of skin. While it is “knowingly committing an intentional crime,” it is “having buddha nature.”

[03:78] The Minister says here “cut a worm in two pieces”: is it certain that, before it is cut, it is one piece? In the everyday life of the buddhas and ancestors, this is not so: from the beginning, the worm is not one piece, nor is it two pieces when one cuts it. We should make concentrated effort and study the words “one” and “two.” Does “the two” in his saying “the two both move” mean that he has taken what they were before they are cut as one? Or that he has taken what lies beyond the buddha as one?@1-100-313 Whether or not the Minister understands or does not understand the words “the two,” do not discard his words. [03:82] To say “the wind and fire haven’t dispersed” must be to make buddha nature appear. Should we take it as buddha nature? Should we take it as wind and fire? We should not say that buddha nature and wind and fire both emerge; we should not say that one emerges and one does not emerge; we should not say that the wind and fire are themselves buddha nature. Therefore, Changsha does not say that the worm has buddha nature; he does not say that the worm has no buddha nature. He simply says, “Don’t have deluded ideas”; he says, “the wind and fire haven’t dispersed.” We should calculate the way of life of buddha nature by the saying of Changsha; we should quietly make concentrated effort on the words “the wind and fire haven’t dispersed.”@1-102-322 What is the reasoning behind his saying “not dispersed”? Does “not dispersed” mean he is saying that the wind and fire have been collected and have not yet reached the point when they will be dispersed? This cannot be the case. “The wind and fire haven’t dispersed” is buddha preaching the dharma; “the undispersed wind and fire” is the dharma preaching buddha. It is like the arrival of the time when a single sound preaches the dharma; it is the time of the arrival of the single sound that is the preaching of the dharma. [03:83] Moreover, to think that buddha nature exists only at the time of birth and not at the time of death is [a case of] little learning and slight understanding. The time of birth is “has buddha nature,” is “has no buddha nature”; the time of death is also “has buddha nature,” is “has no buddha nature.” If we discuss the dispersal and non-dispersal of the wind and fire, it would be the dispersal and non-dispersal of buddha nature. The time that it disperses must be buddha nature existing, must be buddha nature not existing; the time that it has not dispersed must be “having buddha nature,” must be “having no buddha nature.”@1-103-324 Despite this, to cling mistakenly to [the views that] buddha nature is present or not present depending on whether something is moving or not moving, or it is spirit or is not spirit depending on whether something is conscious or not conscious, or it is the nature or is not the nature depending on whether something is knowing or not knowing — these are other paths. “From beginningless kalpas,” that “the deluded,” “acknowledging the knowing spirit,” have taken it as buddha nature, have taken it as “the original person” — what a laugh!@1-103-325To say something further about buddha nature, although we need not be dragged through the mud and drenched with water, it is “fences, walls, tiles, and pebbles.”@1-103-326 When we say something beyond this, what is buddha nature? Shōbōgenzō monge 正法眼藏聞解 (SCZ:4:558) understands it as “arising and ceasing” respectively — i.e., “ceasing” severs and “arising” continues the time in which “arising and ceasing don’t stop.” It is also possible to take the agent as the “confirmation” (benkō辦肯) of the previous sentence. 文中子说：我们要实现人与人之间的和谐、个人与社会的和谐、人与自然的和谐、民族与国家的和谐等，全面发展和谐美好的小康社会，都应在各个方面坚持科学的发展观。而继承和运用中庸之道的思想方法，去实现建设和谐社会的目标，应当是具有中国特色又符合科学规律的一个重要手段。所以中道仍然是建设和谐社会全面发展小康社会的正道。王通的《中说》就是中道，中道是灵活的辩证法，过分地批孔不是中道，过分地捧儒也不是中道；过去不评职称不是中道，现在的滥评职称也不是中道；乱评奖、乱发奖金、乱发文凭,腐败的蔓延，作假的视而不见皆非中道。中道有严格的辩证法，中道是高超的统御术，中道而行，天下安定。 "我对天下事，不即不离，只追随中道而行。"【评析】王通主张实行王道政治，也就是仁政。但如何才能达到推行仁政的目的？世界上的事千变万化，如何才能正确妥善地处理？王通提出必须抓住其根本，这就是要“执中"。执中，就是实行中道，也称中行、中庸，这是儒家思想方法论的核心。什么是中庸之道，过去有人将为人处世中实行折中主义，遇事不表态，哪一边也不得罪的老好好、骑墙派、和稀泥等，说成是中庸之道。这是对中庸的误解和歪曲。所谓中庸之道，就是要求处理一切事务都要以适中为度，不偏不倚。孔子曾说过："过犹不及”（《论语•先进》），这句话意思是处理一件事，如果过了头和没有达到要求是同样不好的。如果我们用现代语言来解释，处理一件事过了头，可称之为"极左”，如果达不到要求，则可称之为"右倾"，我们既要反左，也要反右，才能正确处理。所以"中庸"，绝不是要把左和右的东西混在一起，兼收并蓄。儒家提出的中庸之道，其真实含义就是处理任何事物都应恰到好处，既不可过头，亦不能不足，使一切都达到最完美、最理想的境界。这种主张是符合马克思主义思想方法论的。毛泽东同志说过："中庸观念是孔子的一大发明，一大功绩，是哲学的重大范畴，值得很好地解释一番。"（《毛泽东书信选集》）现在我们要树立科学发展观，建立和谐社会，继承儒家这种中庸观点，是十分重要的，世界上一切事物，都有它内在的规律性，符合事物的内在规律，才能促进其科学发展，达到完美的目的；违背科学规律，必然会导致事物的失衡、失调，而成为发展的障碍。比如种庄稼，要促进其增产，必须从良种培育、科学管理等符合植物生长规律的方法入手，而不能破坏其生长规律去干"拔苗助长"的傻事。 【文中子既称赞了汉朝七个皇帝的英明，又为近几百年中国分裂、战争不断、百姓流离失所而感慨不已，特别是到他的晚年，正是隋炀帝只图一己之乐，不顾百姓死活而实行暴政之时，更令文中子为之忧伤。隋炀帝为了建筑东都洛阳的宫苑，征调了几百万人从事劳役,为了下扬州观赏琼花，怕走路劳累，便又拘役百姓开挖水路，由汴河接通运河，并制造了豪华无比的龙舟以供他乘坐。据史料记载，他乘坐的龙舟高达四层，最上一层有正殿、内殿、朝堂等，多达数百间。此外，还有皇后、王公大臣、侍从等随从船只多达数千只，仅使用民夫在岸上拉纤者便有八万人。还有马步军队列队于两岸，护卫着龙舟行进，每隔五十里，还要在岸上建一座行宫，供皇帝上岸休息。这支庞大船队经过的地方，五百里内的州县，都要供应饮食用物，而且要水陆珍品，一个州县供应的食品，往往上百车之多。种种皇差贡品，州县自然勒令老百姓交纳，弄得民不聊生，受迫害而死者无数。为了求活，百姓们纷纷起来造反，在一些稗官小说中用“三十六处烟尘，七十二路草寇”来形容当时的天下大乱。而隋炀帝对此熟视无睹，仍然只顾自家享乐，实行暴政，对忠心劝谏他的大臣，也毫不留情地杀了不少。这些现实，使文中子得出了 These supplementsWang Tong titled the Li lun 禮論 (Discussions on Rites), Yue lun 樂論 (Discussionson Music), Xu Shu 續書 (The Continued Book of Documents), Xu Shi 續詩 (The Continued Book of Songs), Yuanjing 元經 (The Primal Classic), andZan Yi 讚易 (Elucidation of the Book of Changes), each modeled after one ofthe six classics of the hallowed Confucian canon. Collectively these texts wereknown to Wang Tong’s contemporaries as the Wangshi liu jing 王氏六經(Wang’s Six Classics) or the Xu jing 續經 (Continued Classics). All of Wang Tong’s own writings seem to have been lost by the ninth century,leaving the Zhongshuo as the only source for later generations of scholars toformulate an understanding of his character, beliefs, and ideology.
